newsitem.title: USA: US Southeast spot power prices firm despite storm.
newsitem.headline: US Southeast spot power prices firm despite storm.

text.p: Bulk electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. on Monday remained firm against Friday's levels despite forecasts of Tropical Storm Josephine bringing rain and clouds into the region, market sources said.

Most participants explained the cooling effect from Josephine set a bearish tone for the power market, opposed to a bullish underpinning for the natural gas market because strong winds and choppy water led many pipeline operators to shut-in offshore natgas production in the U.S. Gulf.
Tight transmission constraints in the Southeast had a more supporting effect on spot power prices, they said.
Limited capacity on high-voltage transmission lines offset low demand on the systems of the utilities in the Southeastern Electric Reliability Council (SERC), traders said.
"Their minimum loads are fairly low," noted one Southeast trader.
Peak, firm power during heavy load hours for delivery into the northern part of the Tennessee Valley Authority's (TVA) system was quoted at $15.00-$16.00, up from Friday's $14.50 for Monday.
At the Georgia-Florida border, firm, peak electricity was valued near $22.75 a MWh, compared with Friday's quote of $22.00-$22.75 for Monday power.
TVA was reportedly offering peak, non-firm electricity for Tuesday at $18.00-$18.50 a MWh, up from Friday's $17.50 quote for Monday delivery.
